subject: Re: [junit] Do i really need to write a Test Class ????
msgSnippet: ... Take a look at my recent Ruby example under the subject using JUnit with derived classes and tell me if that s the kind of thing you re thinking about.
messageBody:
On Mon, 7 Jun 2004, Girish Patil wrote:

> WHAT IF I GENERATE THE TEST CLASSES DYNAMICALLY WHERE
> I JUST GIVE CALLS TO ACTUAL METHODS WITH ALL POSSIBLE
> COMBINATIONS WITH OUT WRITTING TEST CODE.

Take a look at my recent Ruby example under the subject "using JUnit
with derived classes" and tell me if that's the kind of thing you're
thinking about.

If not, you'll need to give me another explaination with more detail. It
would help greatly if you provided a complete (though not necessarially
large) code example indicating exactly what lines are the lines of
repetitive code you want to get rid of.

If so, you're basically just SoL in Java; the language is so inflexible
that you're forced into writing a lot of repetitive code. According
to Paul Graham, Lisp- and Scheme-like languages offer you the best
chance of being able to move beyond this, by essentially writing custom
programming languages within the language for particular purpose you
have in mind. After a year or so of looking at this, I'm coming into
violent agreement with him. I've been looking at Ruby to see how one
might do things better while still being enough like Java that other
programmers can transition to it easily.

> I CAN GENERATE TEST CALLS TO THESE METHODS DYNAMICALLY
> AND TEST THEIR VALIDITY

I've given up as a lost cause any serious work in dynamic code
generation directly in Java. Either you use reflection, which is so
prolix anyway that you need to be generating a lot of code to make it
worthwhile, or you write a preprocessor for a custom language, which is
a pain.

The only thing that's really saved my sanity in the last year or so has
been anonymous inner classes that extend other classes.

As an exercise, if anybody's interested in approaching this, try writing
a class that includes a state machine, and testing it thoroughly,
especially for allowable transitions from and to each state. I found
testing this pretty painful last time I had to do it.
